Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
It is generally accepted that a protein's amino acid sequence is optimized so that the molecule consistently folds into a unique, stable 3D shape while avoiding aggregation with other biomolecules. Yet this view is overly simplistic. On the one hand, many proteins are not monolithic structures; for instance, myoglobin must reliably deform to let in oxygen. On the other hand, under certain conditions, proteins may aggregate into amyloid fibers while in a misfolded conformation. Although very complex, these phenomena can still be understood thermodynamically. Proteins are deformable given a sufficiently large native state entropy, while amyloid fibers are stabilized by multiple amino acid contacts within the fiber. Much less understood are the mesoscopic liquid-like aggregates recently found in several protein solutions, including lysozyme, hemoglobin, and gamma-crystallin. These clusters are important as nucleation sites for protein crystals. The objective of this project is to test a microscopic hypothesis for the formation of the mesoscopic clusters by which the clusters result from the formation of long-lived protein complexes stabilized at high densities. The unusually large cluster size stems from the long lifetime of the complexes, which in turn owe their stability to the conformational freedom of constituent protein molecules. A key component of the proposed mechanism is that proteins partially unfold prior to binding and may even undergo domain swapping, whereby protein segments bind to complimentary segments on a different protein. The PIs will employ a combination of dynamic light scattering, Brownian microscopy, amide exchange NMR, and theoretical modeling to test this mechanism in several systems, including proteins barnase, RNase A, hemoglobin, insulin, and lysozyme.

This research is a multidisciplinary effort by a theoretical physical chemist and experimental chemical engineer. A synthesis of a wide range of physicochemical and biochemical measurements and physical modeling will be undertaken to tackle this difficult problem; the outcome is expected to produce fundamental understanding of biological processes and provide new avenues for making new materials. Graduate, undergraduate, and high school students will be trained at the interface between physics, chemistry, and biology. The home institution of the PIs, the University of Houston, is one of the most ethnically diverse research universities in the nation, and is one of only three Hispanic-Serving Institutions in the US. Existing collaborations with local writers and radio personalities will be utilized to publicize the societal benefits of the research. This project is jointly supported by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Physics of Living Systems Program in the Physics Division.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work has shed much needed light on an unsolved problem of biology and chemical physics. Solutions of many proteins exhibit droplets of yet more concentrated protein solution that measure a micron or so across. We have called these droplets the mesoscopic clusters. The clusters are as interesting to a theoretical chemical physics as they are to a structural biologist or doctor. Although containing only a small fraction of the total protein, the clusters serve as nucleation centers for protein crystals, hence the importance to structural biology, where X-ray diffraction off protein crystals remains the most important tool for protein structure determination. Likewise, fibers of mutated hemoglobin nucleate within the mesoscopic clusters leading to the debilitating disease sickle cell anemia. Understanding how the clusters form may provide intimate insight both into the mechanism of the disease and possible ways to mitigate its deleterious effects.

From the more basic perspective, the existence of clusters flies in the face of established paradigms of thermodynamics as pertaining to coexistence of distinct phases of matter, such as vapor and liquid. If prevented from crystallizing, solubilized protein is known to phase separate into a protein-rich and protein-poor solutions in a way that is completely analogous to the formation of fog, which is a suspension of small water droplets in a saturated water vapor. Yet the clusters are not like fog particles since their size does not depend on the degree of saturation of the protein solution. Nor are the clusters micelle-like objects since the concentration of the bulk solution can be varied in their presence.

As a result of the performed research, we have demonstrated that the clusters form according to a radically novel, complicated mechanism. According to this mechanism, the protein molecules do not interact as monolithic objects but, instead, partially unfold while forming transient complexes with each other. These complexes are the more stabilized, the higher the protein concentration. The lifetime of these transient complexes corresponds to a new time scale and a new process: The size of a droplet of a relatively concentrated solution, which hosts large quantities of the complexes, is bounded from below by the distance travelled by a complex before it decays. At the same time, since the complexes are stabilized at high protein concentrations, the cluster size must be determined self-consistently.

We have obtained evidence supporting key components of the above microscopic picture, both experimentally and theoretically. On the experimental front, we have discovered that the properties of clusters are not sensitive to the precise value of the ionic strength of the solution. This surprising and exciting result means that interactions other than electrostatics cause the formation of the clusters. The only remaining candidate is interactions between hydrophobic residues that became solvent-exposed as a result of partial unfolding. Independently, we have established that shear promotes protein unfolding while making the clusters larger. This, among several other experiments, indicates the clusters emerge as a result of the formation of transient complexes between partially unfolded protein molecules. At the same time, we have demonstrated that modifying the solvent does change the total amount of the clusters implying the latter are small droplets of a separate phase that obeys basic notions of thermodynamic stability of solutions.

In view of the standard paradigms of phase equilibrium, how could such small droplets of a metastable phase exist? The results of the theoretical part of our activities provide much needed insight: We have shown that in the presence of transient complex-formation, droplets of a metastable phase could indeed be kinetically stabilized. The analysis, performed at a coarse-grained level, is a complete, internally-consistent treatment that combines thermodynamics and kinetics. The treatment thus predicts a hitherto unknown type of aggregation in equilibrated solutions. The above results also suggest that the protein-rich liquid so commonly observed by structural biologists while attempting to grow protein crystals, is more complex that previously thought; it may well contain so far undocumented transient protein complexes.

We have also confirmed the existence of the mesoscopic clusters for proteins other than lysozyme, hemoglobin, and lumazine synthase. This suggests that a cluster-like mechanism may be more ubiquitous than is currently believed. For instance, the clusters may be the preferred nucleation sites for the amyloid fibers implicated in many diseases such as Alzheimer’s. Thus the clusters may represent a general phenomenon that could be of relevance to many fields ranging from materials science to medicine. In the latter context, the present results suggest a different type of therapy, one that is based not on biochemical mechanisms but on even more basic, physicochemical processes.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/20/2017
Modified by: Vassiliy Lubchenko
